name: benzoic acid, 2-chloro-4-nitro-
Reason: To predict the melting point of 2-chloro-4-nitrobenzoic acid, we start with the basic unit of benzene which has an estimated melting point of 5.5°C. The carboxylic acid group (COOH) significantly increases the melting point due to strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding, and we can estimate this increase to be approximately +110°C. The chloro substituent (Cl) is also electron-withdrawing through inductive effects and can increase the melting point due to polarizability; this effect can be roughly estimated as a +25°C increase. The nitro group (NO2) is a strong electron-withdrawing group and further enhances hydrogen bonding while also contributing to molecular rigidity, which we can approximate as another +30°C increase. Summing these adjustments, the predicted melting point is as follows: 5.5 (benzene) + 110 (carboxylic acid) + 25 (chloro group) + 30 (nitro group).
